editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

note.p: The minor plot is from "El casamiento engañoso" by Cervantes.
The title page is partly in the same setting as Fletcher's "The tragœdy of Rollo duke of Normandy", 1640.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

div.p: Rule a wife and have a wife. A comedy. Acted by his majesty's servants.
Oxford, printed by Leonard Lichfield printer to the university. Anno 1640.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: Pleasure attend ye, and about ye sit
The springs of mirth fancy delight and wit
To stir you up, do not your looks let fall,
Nor to remembrance our late errors call,
Because this day we're Spaniards all again,
The story of our play, and our scene Spain:
The errors too, do not for this cause hate,
Now we present their wit and not their state.
Nor ladies be not angry if you see,
A young fresh beauty, wanton and too free,
Seek to abuse your husband, still 'tis Spain,
No such gross errors in your kingdom reigns,
We're vestals all, and though we blow the fire,
We seldom make it flame up to desire,
Take no example neither to begin,
For some by precedent delight to sin:
Nor blame the poet if he slip aside,
Sometimes lasciviously if not too wide.
But hold your fans close, and then smile at ease,
A cruel scene did never lady please.
Nor gentlemen, pray be not you displeased,
Though we present some men fooled foam diseased,
Some drunk, some mad: we mean not you, you're free,
We tax no farther than our comedy,
You are our friends sit noble then and see.

div.head: Rule a wife and have a wife.
Actus. 1. Scaena. 1.
div.stage: Enter Juan de Castro, and Michael Perez.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Are your companies full colonel?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: No not yet sir:
Nor will not be this month yet, as I reckon.
How rises your command?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: We pick up still, and as our moneys hold out,
We have men come, about that time I think
We shall be full too, many young gallants go.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: And unexperienced,
The wars are dainty dreams to young hot spirits,
Time and experience will allay those visions,
We have strange things to fill our numbers,
There's one don Leon, a strange goodly fellow,
Recommended to me from some noble friends,
For my Alfores, had you but seen his person,
And what a giant's promise it protesteth.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I have heard of him and that he hath served before too.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: But no harm done, nor never meant, don Michael
That came to my ears yet, ask him a question,
he blushes like a girl, and answers little,
To the point less, he wears a sword a good one,
And good clothes too, he is whole skinned, has no hurt yet,
Good promising hopes, I never yet heard certainly
Of any gentleman that saw him angry.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Preserve him, he'll conclude a peace if need be,
Many as strong as he will go along with us,
That swear as valiantly as heart can wish,
Their mouth charged with six oaths at once, and whole on's,
That make the drunken Dutch creep into molehills.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: 'Tis true, such we must look for, but Michael Perez,
When heard you of donna Margaretta, the great heiress.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I hear every hour of her, though I never saw her,
She is the main discourse, noble don Juan de Castro,
How happy were that man could catch this wench up,
And live at ease, she is fair, and young, and wealthy,
Infinite wealthy, and as gracious too
In all her entertainments, as men report.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: But she is proud sir, that I know for certain,
And that coms seldom without wantonness,
He that shall marry her, must have a rare hand.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Would I were married, I would find that wisdom,
With a light rein to rule my wife, if ever woman
Of the most subtlest mould went beyond me,
I would give the boys leave to hoot me out o'th parish.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir there be two gentlewomen attend to speak
With ye.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Wait on them in.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Are they two handsome women?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: They seem so, very handsome, but they are veiled sir.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Thou put'st sugar in my mouth, how it melts with me,
I love a sweet young wench.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Wait on them in I say. Exit serve.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Don Juan.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: How you itch Michael, how you burnish!
Will not this soldier's heat out of your bones yet,
Do your eyes glow now?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: There be two.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Say honest, what shame have you then.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I would fain see that,
I have been in the Indies twice, and have seen strange things,
But two honest women: one I read of once.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Pre thee be modest.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I'll be any thing.

div.stage: Enter servant, donna, Clara, and Estifania veiled.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You are welcome ladies.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Both hooded, I like 'em well though,
They come not for advice in law sure heather,
Maybe they would learn to raise the pick,
I am for 'em. They are very modest, 'tis a fine praeludium.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: With me or with this gentleman,
Would you speak lady?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: With you sir as I guess, Juan de Castro.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Her curtain opens, she is a pretty gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I am the man, and shall be bound to fortune,
I may do any service to your beauties.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Captain, I hear you are marching down to Flanders,
To serve the catholic King.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I am sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I have a kinsman and a noble friend,
Employed in those wars, may be sir you know him,
Don Campusano captain of carbines,
To whom I would request your nobleness,
To give this poor remembrance. A letter.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I shall do it,
I know the gentleman a most worthy captain.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Something in private.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Step aside: I'll serve thee. Ex. Juan. and Clara.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Prithee let me see thy face.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Sir you must pardon me,
Women of our sort that maintain fair memories,
And keep suspect off from their chastities,
Had need wear thicker veils.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I am no blaster of a lady's beauty,
nor bold intruder on her special favours,
I know how tender reputation is,
And with what guards it ought to be preserved lady,
You may to me.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You must excuse me signior, I come
Not here to sell myself.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: As I am a gentleman, by the honour of a souldier●

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I believe you.
I pray you be civil, I believe you would see me,
And when you have seen me, I believe you will like me.
But in a strange place, to a stranger too,
As if I came on purpose to betray you,
Indeed I will not.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I shall love you dear,
And 'tis a sin to fling away affection,
I have no mistress, no desire to honour
Any but your will not this oyster open?
I know not, you have struck me with your modesty,
She will draw sure; so deep, and taken from me?
All the desire I might bestow on others;
Quickly before they come.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Indeed I dare not.
But since I see you are so desirous sir
To view a poor face that can merit nothing
But your repentance.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: It must needs be excellent.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: And with what honesty you ask it of me.
When I am gone let your man follow me,
And view what house I enter, thither come,
For there I dare be bold to appear open.
And as I like your virtuous carriage then,Enter Juan, Cla. a servant.
I shall be able to give welcome to you,
She hath done her business, I must take my leave sir.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I'll kiss your fair white hand, and thank ye lady,
My man shall wait, and I shall be your servant,
Sirrah, come near, hark.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I shall do it faithfully. Exit.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You will command me no more services?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: To be careful of your noble health, dear sir,
That I may ever honour you.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I thank you,
And kiss your hands, wait on the ladies down there.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: You had the honour to see the face that came to you.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: And 'twas a fair one, what was yours, don Michael?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Mine was i'th''clipse, and had a cloud drawn over it
But I believe well, and I hope 'tis handsome,
She had a hand would stir a holy hermit.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You know none of 'em?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Then I do captain,
But I'll say nothing till I see the proof on't,
Sit close don Perez, or your worship's caught,
I fear a fly.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Were those she brought love letters?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: A packet to a kinsman now in Flanders;
Yours was very modest methought .

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Some young unmanaged thing;
But I may live to see —

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: 'Tis worth experience,
Let's walk abroad and view our companies. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: What are you for the wars Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: It may be I,
It may be no, e'en as the humour takes me,
If I find peace amongst the female creatures,
And easy entertainment, I'll stay at home,
I am not so far obliged yet to long marches,
And mouldy biscuits to run mad for honour,
When you are all gone I have my choice before me.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Of which hospital thou wilt sweat in; wilt thou
Never leave whoring?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: There is less danger in't then gunning Sanchio,
Though we be shot sometimes the shot's not mortal,
Besides it breaks no limbs.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: But it disables 'em,
dost thou see how thou pullest thy legs after thee, as they
Hung by points.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Better to pull 'em thus then walk on wooden ones,
Serve bravely for a billet to support me.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Fie, fie, 'tis base.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Dost thou count it base to suffer?
Suffer abundantly, 'tis the crown of honour;
You think it nothing to lie twenty days
Under a surgeon's hands that has no mercy.

sp.speaker: Sanch
sp.l: As thou hast done I am sure but I perceive now
Why you desire to stay, the orient heiress,
The Margaretta sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I would I had her.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: They say she will marry.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Yes, I think she will.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: And marry suddenly as report goes too,
She fears her youth will not hold out Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Alon,
sp.l: I would I had the sheathing on't.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: They say too
She has a greedy eye that must be fed
With more than one man's meat.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Would she were mine,
I would cater for her well enough: but Sanchio,
There be too many great men that adore her,
Princes, and prince's fellows that claim privilege.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Yet those stand off ith' way of marriage,
To be tied to a man's pleasure is a second labour.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: She has bought a brave house here in town.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I have heard so.

sp.speaker: Alon
sp.l: If she convert it now to pious uses,
And bid poor gentlemen welcome.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: When comes she to it?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Within these two days, she is in the country yet,
And keeps the noblest house.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Then there's some hope of her,
Wilt thou go my way?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: No, no, I must leave you
And repair to an old gentlewoman
that has credit with her, that can speak a good word.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Send thee good fortune, but make thy body sound first.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I am a soldier,
And too sound a body becomes me not,
Farewell Sanchio. Exit.

div.stage: Enter a servant of Michael Perez.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: 'Tis this● or that house, or I have lost mine aim,
They are both fair buildings, she walked plaguy fast,Ent. Estif.
And hereabouts I lost her, stay, that's she,
'Tis very she, — she makes me a low curtsy,
Let me note the place, the street I well remember. Exit.
She is in again, certain some noble lady,
How happy should I be if she love my master:
A wondrous goodly house, here are brave lodgings,
And I shall sleep now like an emperor,
And eat abundantly I thank my fortune,
I'll back with speed and bring him happy tidings. Exit.
What should it mean, that in such haste
We are sent for?
Belike the lady Margaret has some business
She would break to us in private.
It should seem so.
'Tis a good lady, and a wise young lady.
And virtuous enough too I warrant ye
For a young woman of her years: 'tis pity
To load her tender age with too much virtue.
'Tis more sometimes than we can well away with.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Good morrow ladies.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Morrow my good madam.
How does the sweet young beauty, lady Margaret?
Has she slept well after her walk last night?
Are her dreams gentle to her mind?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: All's well,
She's very well, she sent for you thus suddenly
To give her counsel in a business
That much concerns her.
She does well and wisely,
To ask the counsel of the ancientest madam,
Our years have run through many things she knows not.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: She would fain marry.
'Tis a proper calling,
And well beseems her years, who would she yoke with?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: That's left to argue on, I pray come in
And break your fast, drink a good cup or two,
To strengthen your understandings, then she'll tell ye.
And good wine breeds good counsel,
We'll yield to ye. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Juan de Castro, and leon.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Have you seen any service?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Everywhere .

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What office bore ye?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: None, I was not worthy.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What captains know you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: None, they were above me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Were you never hurt?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Not that i well remember,
But once i stole a hen, and then they beat me;
Pray ask me no long questions, i have an ill memory.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: This is an ass, did you never draw your sword yet?

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: Not to do any harm I thank heaven for't.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Nor ne'er ta'en prisoner?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No, ● ran away,
For ● had ne'er no money to redeem me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Can you endure a drum?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It makes my head ache.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Are you not valiant when you are drunk?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I think not, but I am loving sir.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What a lump is this man,
Was your father wise?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Too wise for me I'm sure,
For he gave all he had to my younger brother.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: That was no foolish part I'll bear you witness.
Canst thou lie with a woman?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I think I could make shift sir,
But I am bashful.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: In the night?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I know not,
Darkness indeed may do some good upon me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Why art thou sent to me to be my officer,
Ay, and commended too, when thou dar'st not fight?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: There be more officers of my opinion,
Or I am cozened sir, men that talk more too.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: How wilt thou scape a bullet?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Why by chance,
They aim at honourable men, alas I am none sir.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: This fellow has some doubts in's talk that strikes me,
He cannot be all fool: welcome Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: What have you got there temperance into your company?
The spirit of peace? we shall have warsEnt. Caca.
By th'ounce then, oh here's another pompion,
Let him loose for luck's sake, the crammed son
Of a starved usurer, Cacafogo, both their brains buttered,
Cannot make two spoonfuls.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: My father's dead: I am a man of war too,
Moneys, demeans; I have ships at sea too,
Captains.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Take heed o'th Hollanders, your ships may leak else.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I scorn the Hollanders, they are my drunkards.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Put up your gold sir, I'll borrow it else.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I am satisfied, you shall not,
Come out, I know thee, meet mine anger instantly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I never wronged ye.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Thou hast wronged mine honour,
Thou lookest upon my mistress thrice lasciviously,
I'll make it good.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Do not heat yourself, you will surfeit.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Thou want'st my money too, with a pair of base bones,
In whom there was no truth, for which I beat thee,
I beat thee much, now I will hurt thee dangerously.
This shall provoke thee. He strikes.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: You struck too low by a foot sir.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You must get a ladder when you would beat
This fellow.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I cannot choose but kick again, pray pardon me.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Hadst thou not asked my pardon, I had killed thee,
I leave thee as a thing despised, assoles manus a vostra siniare a maistre. Exit Caca.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: You have scaped by miracle, there is not in all Spain,
A spirit of more fury than this fire drake.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I see he is hasty, and I would give him leave,
To beat me soundly if he would take my bond.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What shall I do with this fellow?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Turn him off,
He will infect the camp with cowardice,
If he go with thee.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: About some week hence sir,
If I can hit upon no abler officer,
You shall hear from me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I desire no better. Exit.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You have made me now too bountiful amends, lady
For your strict carriage when you saw me first,
These beauties were not meant to be concealed,
It was a wrong to hide so sweet an object,
I could now chide ye, but it shall be thus,
No other anger ever touch your sweetness.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You appear to me so honest, and so civil,
Without a blush sir, I dare bid ye welcome.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Now let me ask your name.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: 'Tis Estifanie, the heir of this poor place.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Poor do you call it,
There's nothing that I cast mine eyes upon,
But shows both rich and admirable, all the rooms
Are hung as if a Princess were to dwell here,
The gardens, orchards, every thing so curious:
Is all that plate your own too?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: 'Tis but little,
only for present use, I have more and richer,
When need shall call, or friends compel me use it,
The suits you see of all the upper chambers,
Are those that commonly adorn the house,
I think I have besides, as fair as Seville
Or any town in Spain can parallel.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Now if she be not married, I have some hopes,
Are you a maid?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You make me blush to answer,
I ever was accounted so to this hour,
And that's the reason that I live retired sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Then would I counsel you to marry presently,
If I can get her, I am made for ever,
For every year you lose, you lose a beauty,
A husband now an honest careful husband,
Were such a comfort, will ye walk above stairs.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: This place will fit our talk, 'tis fitter far sir,
Above there are day-beds, and such temptations
I dare not trust sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: She is excellent wise withal too.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You named a husband, I am not so strict sir,
Nor tied unto a virgin's solitariness,
But if an honest, and a noble one,
Rich, and a soldier, for so I have vowed he shall be,
Were offered me, I think I should accept him,
But above all he must love.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: He were base else,
There's comfort ministered in the word soldier,
How sweetly should I live.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I am not so ignorant, but that I know well,
How to be commanded,
And how again to make myself obeyed sir,
I waste but little, I have gathered much,
My rial not the less worth, when 'tis spent,
If spent by my direction, to please my husband,
I hold it as indifferent in my duty,
To be his maid i'th kitchen, or his cook,
As in the hall to know myself the mistress.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Sweet, rich, and provident, now fortune stick
To me; I am a soldier, and a bachelor, lady,
And such a wife as you, I could love infinitely,
They that use many words, some are deceitful,
I long to be a husband, and a good one,
For 'tis most certain I shall make a precedent
For all that follow me to love their ladies,
I am young you see, able I would have you think too,
If't please you know, try me before you take me,
'Tis true I shall not meet in equal wealth
With ye, but jewels, chains, such as the war
Has given me, a thousand ducats I dare
Presume on in ready gold, now as your
Care may handle it, as rich clothes too, as
Any he bears arms lady.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You are a true gentleman, and fair, I see by ye,
And such a man I had rather take.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Pray do so, I'll have a priest o'th sudden.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: And as suddenly you will repent too.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I'll be hanged or drowned first,
By this and this, and this kiss.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You are a flatterer,
But I must say there was something when ● saw you.
First, in that most noble face, that stirred my fancy.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I'll stir it better ere you sleep sweet lady,
I'll send for all my trunks and give up all to ye,
Into your own dispose, before I bed ye,
And then sweet wench.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You have the art to cozen me. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus 2. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter Margaretta, and two ladies, and Altea.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: Sit down and give me your opinions seriously.
You say you have a mind to marry lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I have for to preserve my credit,
yet not so much for that as for my state ladies,
Conceive me right, there lies the main o'th question,
Credit I can redeem, money will imp it,
But when my money's gone, when the law shall
Cease that, and for incontinency strip me
Of all.
Do you find your body so malicious that way.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I find it as all bodies are that are young and lusty,
Lazy, and high fed, I desire my pleasure
And pleasure I must have.
'Tis fit you should have,
Your years require it, and 'tis necessary,
As necessary as meat to a young lady,
Sleep cannot nourish more.
But might not all this be, and keep ye single.
You take away variety in marriage,
The abundance of the pleasure you are barred then,
Is't not abundance that you aim at.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Yes why was I made a woman.
And every day a new?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why fair and young but to use it.
You are still i'th right, why would you marry then.
Because a husband stops all doubts in this point,
And clears all passages.
What husband mean ye.
A husband of an easy faith a fool,
Made by her wealth, and moulded to her pleasure,
One though he see himself become a monster,
Shall hold the door, and entertain the maker.
You grant there may be such a man.
Yes marry, but how to bring 'em to this rare perfection.
They must be chosen so, things of no honour,
Nor outward honesty.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: No 'tis no matter,
I care not what they are, so they be lusty.
Methinks now a rich lawyer, some such fellow,
That carries credit, and a face of awe,
but lies with nothing but his client's business.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: No there's no trusting them, they are too subtle,
The law has moulded they of natural mischief.
Then some grave governor,
Some man of honour, yet an easy man.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: If he have honour I am undone, I'll none such,
I'll have a lusty man, honour will cloy me.
'Tis fit ye should lady;
And to that end, with search and wit and labour,
I have found one out, a right one and a perfect,
He is made as strong as brass, is of brave years too,
And doughty of complexion.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Is he a gentleman?
Yes and a soldier, as gentle as you would wish him,
A good fellow, wears good clothes.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Those I'll allow him,
They are for my credit, does he understand,
But little?
Very little.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: 'Tis the better.
Has not the wars bred him up to anger?
No, he will not quarrel with a dog that bites him,
Let him be drunk or sober, is one silence.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Has no capacity what honour is?
For that's the soldier's god.
Honour's a thing too subtle for his wisdoms
If honour lie in eating, he is right honourable.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Is he so goodly a man do you say?
As you shall see lady,
But to all this is but a trunk.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I would have him so,
I shall add branches to him to adorn him,
Go, find me out this man, and let me see him,
If he be that motion that you tell me of,
And make no more noise, I shall entertain him,
Let him be here.
He shall attend your ladyship. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Why thou art not married indeed.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: No, no, pray think so,
Alas I am a fellow of no reckoning,
Not worth a lady's eye.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Wouldst thou steal a fortune,
And make none of all thy friends acquainted with it▪
Nor bid us to thy wedding.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: No indeed,
There was no wisdom in't, to bid an artist,
An old seducer to a female banquet,
I can cut up my pie without your instructions.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Was it the wench i'th veil.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Basto 'twas she,
The prettiest rogue that ere you looked upon,
The lovingest thief.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: And is she rich withal too.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: A mine, a mine, there is no end of wealth colonel.
I am an ass, a bashful fool, prithee colonel,
How do thy companies fill now.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You are merry sir,
You intend a safer war at home belike now.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I do not think I shall fight much this year colonel,
I find myself given to my ease a little,
I care not if I sell my foolish company,
They are things of hazard.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: How it angers me,
This fellow at first sight should win a lady,
A rich young wench, and I that have consumed
My time and art in searching out their subtleties,
Like a fooled alchemist blow up my hopes still,
When shall we come to thy house and be freely merry.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: When I have managed her a little more,
I have a house to entertain an army.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: If thy wife be fair, thou wilt have few less
Come to thee.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: But where they'll get entertainment is the point signior.
I beat no drum.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: You need none but her taber,
May be I'll march after a month or two,
to get me a fresh stomach, I find colonel
A wantonness in wealth, methinks I agree not with,
'Tis such a trouble to be married too,
And have a thousand things of great importance,
Jewels and plates, and fooleries molest me,
To have a man's brains whimsied with his wealth:
Before I walked contentedly.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My mistress sir is sick, because you are absent,
She mourns and will not eat.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Alas my jewel,
Come I'll go with thee, gentlemen your fair leaves,
You see I am tide a little to my yoke,
Pray pardon me, would ye had both such loving wives.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I thank yeExit. Perez Serv.
For your old boots, never be blank Alonzo,
Because this fellow has out stripped thy fortune,
Tell me ten days hence what he is, and how
The gracious state of matrimony stands with him,
Come, let's to dinner, when Margarita comes
We'll visit both, it may be then your fortune. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Is he come?
Yes madam, has been here this half hour,
I have questioned him of all that you can ask him,
And find him as fit as you had made the man,
He will make the goodliest shadow for iniquity.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Have ye searched him ladies?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Is a man at all points, a likely man.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Call him in Altea. Exit lady.
A man of a good presence, pray ye come this way,
Of a lusty body, is his mind so.
Pray ye question him, and if you find him not
Fit for your purpose, shake him off, there's no harm done.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Can you love a young lady? How he blushes.
Leave twirling of your hat, and hold your head up,
and speak to'th lady.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes, I think I can,
I must be taught, I know not what it means madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You shall be taught, and can you when she pleases
Go ride abroad, and stay a week or two?
You shall have men and horses to attend ye,
And money in your purse.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes I love riding,
And when I am from home I am so merry.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Be as merry as you will: can you as handsomely
When you are sent for back, come with obedience,
And do your duty to the lady loves you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes sure, I shall.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: And when you see her friends here,
Or noble kinsmen, can you entertain
Their servants in the cellar, and be busied,
And hold your peace, whate'er you see or hear of.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Twere fit I were hanged else.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Let me try your kisses,
How the fool shakes, I will not eat ye sir,
Beshrew my heart he kisses wondrous manly,
Can ye do any thing else?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Indeed I know not;
But if your ladyship will please to instruct me,
Sure I shall learn.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You shall then be instructed;
If I should be this lady that affects ye,
Nay say I marry ye?
Hark to the lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What money have ye?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: None madam, nor friends,
I wood do any thing to serve your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You must not look to be my Mr. sir,
Nor talk ith' house as though you wore the breeches,
No, nor command in any thing.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will not.
Alas I am not able, I have no wit madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Nor do not labour to arrive at any,
'twill spoil your head I take ye upon charity
And like a servant ye must be unto me,
As I behold your duty I shall love ye,
And as you observe me, I may chance lie with ye,
Can you mark these.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes indeed forsooth.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: There is one thing,
That if I take ye in I put ye from me,
Utterly from me, you must not be saucy,
No, nor at any time familiar with me,
Scarce know me, when I call ye not.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will not, alas I never knew myself sufficiently.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Nor must not now.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I'll be a dog to please ye.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Indeed you must fetch and carry as I appoint ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I were too blame else.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Kiss me again; a strong fellow,
There is a vigour in his lips: if you see me
Kiss any other, twenty in an hour sir,
You must not start, nor be offended.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: No, if you kiss a thousand I shall be contented,
It will the better teach me how to please ye.
I told ye madam,

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: 'Tis the man I wished for; the less you speak.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I'll never speak again madam,
But when you charge me, then I'll speak softly too.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Get me a priest, I'll wed him instantly,
But when you are married sir, you must wait
Upon me, and see you observe my laws.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Else you shall hang me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I'll give ye better clothes when you deserve 'em,
Come in, and serve for witnesses.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We shall madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: And then away to'th city presently,
I'll to my new house and new company.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: A thousand crowns are thine, and I am a made man.
Do not break out too soon.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I know my time wench. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Clara, and Estifania with a paper.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: What have you caught him?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: And do you find him
A man of those hopes that you aimed at?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Yes too,
And the most kind man● and the ablest also
To give a wife content, he is sound as old wine,
And to his soundness rises on the palate,
And there's the man; I find him rich too Clara.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Hast thou married him.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: What dost thou think I fish without a bait wench?
I bob for fools? he is mine own I have him,
I told thee what would tickle him like a trout,
And as I cast it so I caught him daintily,
And all he has I have stowed at my devotion.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Does thy lady know this? she is coming now to town,
Now to live here in this house.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Let her come,
She shall be welcome, I am prepared for her,
She is mad sure if she be angry at my fortune,
For what I have made bold.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Dost thou not love him?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Yes, entirely well,
As long as there he stays and looks no farther
Into my ends, but when he doubts, I hate him,
And that wise hate will teach me how to cozen him,
How to decline their wives, and curb their manners,
To put a stern and strong rein to their natures,
And holds he is an ass not worth acquaintance,
That cannot mould a devil to obedience,
I owe him a good turn for these opinions,
And as I find his temper I may pay him. Enter Perez.
O here he is, now you shall see a kind man.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: My Estifania, shall we to dinner lamb,
I know thou stayest for me.

sp.speaker: Estif
sp.l: I cannot eat else.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I never enter but methinks a paradise
appears about me.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You are welcome to it sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I think I have the sweetest seat in Spain wench,
Methinks the richest too, we'll eat ith' garden
In one o'th arbours, there 'tis cool and pleasant,
And have our wine cold in the running fountain
Who's that?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: A friend of mine sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Of what breeding?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: A gentlewoman sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: What business has she?
Is she a learned woman i'th mathematics,
Can she tell fortunes?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: More than I know sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Or has she ere a letter from a kinswoman,
That must be delivered in my absence wife,
Or comes she from the doctor to salute ye,
And learn your health, she looks not like a confessor.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: What need all this, why are you troubled sir.
What do you suspect, she cannot cuckold ye,
She is a woman sir, a very woman.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Your very woman may do very well sir
Towards the matter, for though she cannot perform it
In her own person, she may do it by proxy,
Your rarest jugglers work still by conspiracy.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Cry ye mercy husband, you are jealous then,
And happily suspect me.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: No indeed wife.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Methinks you should not till you have more cause
And clearer too: I am sure you have heard say husband,
A woman forced will free herself through iron,
A happy, calm, and good wife discontented
May be taught tricks.

sp.speaker: Perez
sp.l: No, no, I do but jest with ye.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Tomorrow friend I'll see you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I shall leave ye
Till then, and pray all may go sweetly with ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Why where's this girl, who's at the door. Knock.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Who knocks there?
Is't for the King ye come, you knock so boisterously?
Look to the door. Enter maid.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: My lady, as I live mistress, my lady's come,
She's at the door, I peeped through, and I saw her,
And a stately company of ladies with her.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: This was a week too soon, but I must meet with her,
And set a new wheel going, and a subtle one,
Must blind this mighty Mars, or I am ruined.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: What are they at door?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Such my Michael
As you may bless the day they entered here,
Such for our good.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Nay, 'twill be better
If you will let me but dispose the business,
And be a stranger to it, and not disturb me,
What have I now to do but to advance your fortune.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Do, I dare trust thee, I am ashamed I am angry,
I find thee a wise young wife.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I'll wise your worship
Before I leave ye, pray ye walk by and say nothing,
Only salute him, and leave the rest to me sir,
I was born to make ye a man.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: The rogue speaks heartily,
Her good will colours in her cheeks, I am born to love her.
I must be gentler to these tender natures,
A soldiers rude harsh words befit not ladies,
Nor must we talk to them as we talk to
Our officers, I'll give her way, for 'tis for me she
Works now, I am husband, heir, and all she has.
sp.stage: Enter Marg. Estif. Leon, Altea, and ladies.
sp.l: Who are these, what flaunting things, a woman
Of rare presence, excellent fair, this is too big
For a bawdy house, too open seated too.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: My husband lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You have gained a proper man.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Whate'er I am, I am your servant lady. Kisses.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Sir, be ruled now,
And I shall make ye rich, this is my cousin,
That gentleman dotes on her, even to death, see how he observes her.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: She is a goodly woman.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: She is a mirror,
But she is poor, she were for a prince's side else,
This house she has brought him too as to her own,
And presuming upon me, and upon my courtesy,
Conceive me short, he knows not but she is wealthy,
Or if she did know otherwise, 'twere all one,
He is so far gone.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Forward, she has a rare face.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: This we must carry with discretion husband,
And yield unto her for four days.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Yield our house up, our goods and wealth.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: All this is but in seeming
To milk the lover on, do you see this writing,
200 a year when they are married,
Has she sealed too for our good; the time's unfit now,
I'll show it you tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: All the house.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: All, all, and we'll remove too, to confirm him.
They'll into th' country suddenly again
After they are matched, and then she'll open to him.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: The whole possession wife, look what you do,
A part o'th house.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: No, no, they shall have all,
And take their pleasure too, 'tis for our advantage,
Why, what's four days, had you a sister sir,
A niece or mistress that required this courtesy,
And should I make a scruple to do you good?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: If easily it would come back.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I swear sir,
As easily as it came on, is't not pity
To let such a gentlewoman for a little help,
You give away no house.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Clear but that question.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I'll put the writings into your hand.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Well then.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: And you shall keep them safe.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I am satisfied; wood I had the wench so too▪

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: When she has married him,
So infinite his love is linked unto her,
You, ay, or any one that helps at this pinch
May have heaven knows what.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I'll remove the goods straight,
And take some poor house by, 'tis but for four days.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I have a poor old friend; there we'll be.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: 'Tis well then.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Go handsome off, and leave the house clear.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: That little stuff we'll use shall follow after;
And a boy to guide ye, peace and we are made both.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Come, let's go in, are all the rooms kept sweet wench.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: They are sweet and neat. Exit Per.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why where's your husband?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Gone madam.
When you come to your own he must give place lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Well, send you joy, you would not let me know't,
Yet I shall not forget ye.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Thank your ladyship. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus 3. Scaena 1.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Are you at ease now, is your heart at rest,
Now you have got a shadow, an umbrella
To keep the scorching world's opinion
From your fair credit.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I am at peace Altea.
If he continue but the same he shows,
And be a master of that ignorance
He outwardly professes, I am happy,
The pleasure I shall live in and the freedom
Without the squint-eye of the law upon me,
or prating liberty of tongues, that envy.
You are a made woman.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: But if he should prove now
A crafty and dissembling kind of husband,
One read in knavery, and brought up in the art
Of villainy concealed.
My life, an innocent.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: That's it I aim at,
That's it I hope too, then I am sure I rule him,
For innocents are like obedient children
Brought up under a hard mother in law, a cruel,
Who being not used to breakfasts and collations,
When they have course bread offered 'em, are thankful,
And take it for a favour too, are the rooms
Made ready to entertain my friends, I long to dance now
And to be wanton; let me have a song, is the great couch up,
The Duke of Medina sent?
'Tis up and ready.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: And day beds in all chambers?
In all lady,
Your house is nothing now but various pleasures
The gallants begin to gaze too.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Let 'em gaze on,
I was brought up a courtier, high and happy,
And company is my delight, and courtship,
And handsome servants at my will, where's my good husband▪
Where does he wait?
He knows his distance madam,
I warrant ye, he is busy in the cellar
Amongst his fellow servants, or asleep,
Till your command awake him.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: 'Tis well Altea. Enter Leon.
It should be so, my ward I must preserve him,
Who sent for him, how dare he come uncalled for,
His bonnet on too.
Sure he sees you not.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: How scornfully he looks.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Are all the chambers
decked and adorned thus for my lady's pleasure,
New hangings every hour for entertainments
And new plate bought, new jewels to give lustre.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: They are, and yet there must be more and richer,
It is her will.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Hum, is it so, 'tis excellent,
It is her will too, to have feasts and banquets,
Revels and masques

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: She ever loved 'em dear,
And we shall have the bravest house kept now sir,
I must not call ye master she has warned me▪
Nor must not put my hat off to ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis no fashion,
What though I be her husband, I am your fellow,
I may cut first.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: That's as you shall deserve sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: And when I lie with her.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: May be I'll light ye.
On the same point you may do me that service.

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.l: Madam, the Duke Medina with some captains
Will come to dinner, and have sent are wine,
And their best services.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: They shall be welcome,
See all be ready in the noblest fashion,
The house perfumed, now I shall take my pleasure,
And not my neighbour justice maunder at me,
Go, get your best clothes on, but till I call ye,
Be sure you be not seen, dine with the gentlewomen,
And behave yourself cleanly sir, 'tis for my credit.
Madam, the lady Julia.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: That's a bawd,
A three piled bawd, bawd major to the army.
Ha● brought her coach to wait upon your ladyship,
And to be informed if you will take the air this morning.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: The neat air of her nunnery.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Tell her no, i'th afternoon I'll call on her.
I will madam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why are not you gone to prepare yourself,
May be you shall be sewer to the first course,
A portly presence, Alten he looks lean,
'Tis a wash knave, he will not keep his flesh well.
A willing, madam▪ one that needs no spurring.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Faith madam, in my little understanding,
You had better entertain your honest neighbours
Your friends about ye, that may speak well of ye,
And give a worthy mention of your bounty.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: How now what's this?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis only to persuade ye,
Courtiers are but tickle things to deal withal,
A kind of marchpane men that will not last madam,
An egg and pepper goes farther than their potions,
And in a well built body a poor parsnip
Will play his prize, above their strong potabiles.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The fellows mad.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: He that shall counsel ladies,
That have both liquorish and ambitious eyes,
I● either ●ad, or drunk, let him speak gospel.
He breaks out modestly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Pray ye be not angry,
My indiscretion has made bold to tell ye,
What you'll find true.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou darest not talk.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Not much madam,
You have a tie upon your servants tongue,
He dares not be so bold as reason bids him,
'Twere fit there were a stronger on your temper,
Ne'er look so stern upon me I am your husband,
But what are husbands, read the new world's wonders,
Such husbands as this monstrous world produces,
And you will scarce find such deformities,
They are shadows to conceal your venial virtues,
Sails to your mills, that grind with all occasions,
Balls that lie by you, to wash out your stains,
And bills nailed up with horn before your storeys,
to rent out last.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Do you hear him talk?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I have done madam,
An ox once spoke, as learned men deliver,
Shortly I shall be such, then I'll speak wonders,
Till when I tie myself to my obedience. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: First I'll untie myself, did you mark the gentleman,
How boldly and how saucily he talked,
And how unlike the lump I took him for,
The piece of ignorant dough, he stood up to me
And mated my commands, this was your providence,
Your wisdom, to elect this gentleman,
Your excellent forecast in the man, your knowledge,
What think ye now.
I think him an ass still,
This boldness some of your people have blown
Into him, this wisdom too with strong wine,
'Tis a tyrant, and a philosopher also, and finds
Out reasons.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll have my cellar locked, no school kept there▪
Nor no discovery I'll t●rne my drunkards,
Such as are understanding in their draughts,
And dispute learnedly the whyes and wherefores,
To grass immediately, I'll keep all fools,
Sober or drunk, still fools that shall know nothing,
Nothing belongs to mankind, but obedience,
And such a hand I'll keep over this husband.
He will fall again, my life he cries by this time,
Keep him from drink, he has a high constitution.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Shall I wear my new suit madam?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: No your old clothest
And get you into the country presently,
And see my hawks well trained, you shall have victuals,
Such as are fit for saucy palates sir,
And lodgings with the hinds it is too good too.
Good madam be not so rough, with repentance,
You see now he's come round again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I see not what I expect to see.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You shall see madam, if it shall please your ladyship.
He's humbled,
Forgive good lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Well go get you handsome,
And let me hear no more.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Have ye yet no feeling,
I'll pinch ye to the bones then my proud lady. Exit.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: See you preserve him thus upon my favour,
You know his temper, tie him to the grindstone,
The next rebellion I'll be rid of him,
I'll have no needy rascals, I tie to me,
Dispute my life, come in and see all handsome.
I hope to see you so too, I have wrought ill else. Exit.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Shall I never return to mine own house again,
We are lodged here in the miserablest dog-hole,
A conjurer's circle gives content above it,
A hawks mew is a princely palace to it,
We have a bed no bigger than a basket,
And there we lie like butter clapped together,
And sweat ourselves to sawee immediately,
The fumes are infinite inhabit here too;
And to that so thick, they cut like marmalade,
So various too, they'll pose a gold finder,
Never return to mine own paradise?
Why wife I say, why Estifania.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Within.I am going presently.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Make hast good jewel,
I am like the people that live in the sweet lands:
I die I die if I stay but one day more here,
My lungs are rotten with the damps that rise,
And I cough nothing now but stinks of all sorts,
The inhabitants we have are two starved rats,
For they are not able to maintain a cat here,
And those appear as fearful as two devils,
They have eat a map of the whole world up already,
And if we stay a night we are gone for company,
there's an old woman that's now grown to marble,
Dried in this brick hill, and she sits i'th chimney,
Which is but three tiles raised like a house of cards,
The true proportion of an old smoked Sibyl,
There is a young thing too that nature meant
For a maid servant, but 'tis now a monster,
She has a husk about her like a chestnut
With basinesse, and living under the line here,
And these two make a hollow sound together,
Like frogs or winds between two doors that murmur
Mercy deliver me, oh are you come wife,
Shall we be free again.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I am now going,
And you shall presently to your own house sir,
The remembrance of this small vexation,
Will be argument of mirth for ever:
By that time you have said your orisons,
And broke your fast, I shall be back and ready,
To usher you to your old content, your freedom.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Break my neck rather, is there any thing here to eat
But one another, like a race of cannibals,
A piece of buttered wall you think is excellent,
Let's have our house again immediately,
And pray ye take heed unto the furniture,
None be embezzled.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Not a pin I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: And let 'em instantly depart.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: They shall both,
There's reason in all courtesies they must both,
For by this time I know she has acquainted him,
And has provided too she sent me word sit,
And will give over gratefully unto you.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I'll walk i'th churchyard,
The dead cannot offend more than these living,
An hour hence I'll expect ye.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I'll not fail sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And do you hear, let's have a handsome dinner,
and see all things be decent as they have been,
And let me have a strong bath to restore me,
I stink like a stall-fish shambles, or an oil shop.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You shall have all, which some interpret nothing,
I'll send ye people for the trunks afore hand,
And for the stuff.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Let 'em be known and honest,
And do my service to your niece.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I shall sir,
But if I come not at my hour come thither,
That they may give you thanks for your fair courtesy,
And pray ye be brave for my sake.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I observe ye. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Juan de Castro, Sancho, and Cacafogo.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Thou art very brave.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I have reason, I have money.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Is money reason.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Yes and ruin too captain,
If ye have no money you're an ass.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Ye have meaner, ever thank him that has money.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Wilt thou lend me any?

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Not a far thing captain,
Captains are casual things.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Why so are all men, thou shalt have my bond.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Nor bonds nor fetters captain,
My money is mine own, I make no doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What dost thou do with it?

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Put it to pious uses,
Buy wine and wenches, and undo young coxcombs,
That would undo me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Are those hospitals?

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: I first provide to fill my hospitals,
With creatures of mine own that I know wretched,
And then I build, those are more bound to pray for me,
Besides I keep th'inheritance in my name still.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: A provident charity, are you for the war's sir?

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: I am not poor enough to be soldier,
nor have i'faith enough to ward a bullet.
This is no lining for a trench I take it.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Ye have said wisely.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Had you but my money,
You would swear it colonel, I had rather drill at home,
A hundred thousand crowns, and with more honour,
Then exercise ten thousand fools with nothing,
A wise man safely feeds, fools cut their fingers.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: A right state-usurer, why dost thou not marry,
And live a reverend justice.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Is't not nobler to command a reverent justice, than to be one,
And for a wife, what need I marry captain,
When every courteous fool, that owes me money.
Owes me his wife too, to appease my fury.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Wilt thou go to dinner with us.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: I will go, and view the pearl of Spain, the orient
Fair one, the rich one too, and I will be respected,
I bear my patent here, I will talk to her,
And when your captain's ships shall stand a loose,
And pick your noses, I will pick the purse,
Of her affection.

sp.speaker: Juan
sp.l: The Duke dines there today too, the Duke of Medina.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Let the King dine there,
He owes me money, and so far's my creature,
And certainly I may make bold with mine own captain.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Thou wilt eat monstrously.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Like a true born Spaniard,
Eat as I were in England where the beef grows,
And I will drink abundantly and then,
Talk ye as wantonly as Ovid did,
To stir the intellectuals of the ladies,
I learned it of my father's amorous scrivener.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: If we should play now, you must supply me.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: You must pawn a horse troop,
And then have at ye colonel.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Come let's go.
This rascal will make rare sport, how the ladies
Will laugh him, leave ager.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: If I light on him I'll make his purse sweat too.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Will ye lead gentlemen. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Perez, an old woman, and maid,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nay pray ye come out, and let me understand ye,
And tune your pipe a little higher lady,
I'll hold ye fast: rub, how came my trunks open,
And my goods gone, what picklock spirit.

sp.speaker: Old Wom●
sp.l: Ha what would ye have?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My goods again, how came my trunks all open.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Are your trunks open?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes and clothes gone,
And chains, and jewels, how she smells like hung beef,
The palsy and picklocks, fie how she belches,
The spirit of garlic.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Where's your gentlewoman?
The young fair woman.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What's that to my question,
She is my wife: and gone about my business.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Is she your wife sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes sir, is that wonder;
Is the name of wife unknown here.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Is she truly, truly your wife.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I think so for I married her,
It was no vision sure.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: She has the keys sir,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I know she has, but who has all my goods spirit.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: If you be married to that gentlewoman,
You are a wretched man, she has twenty husbands.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: She tells you true.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: And she has cozened all sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The devil she has, I had a fair house with her,
That stands hard by, and furnished royally.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: You are cozened too, 'tis none of hers good gentleman,
It is a lady's, what's the lady's name wench.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: The lady Margarita, she was her servant
And kept the house, but going from her sir,
For some lewd tricks she played.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Plague a the devil,
am I i'th full meridian of my wisdom
Cheated by a stale quean, what kind of lady
Is that that owes the house?

sp.speaker: Old. woman
sp.l: A young sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Of a low stature?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: She is indeed but little, but she is wondrous faire●

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I feel I am cozened.
Now I am sensible I am undone,
This is the very woman sure, that cozen
She told me would entreat but for four days,
To make the house hers, I am entreated sweetly.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: When she went out this morning, that I saw sir,
She had two women at the door attending,
And there she gave 'em things, and loaded 'em,
But what they were, I heard your trunks to open,
If they be yours.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: They were mine while they are laden,
But now they have cast their calves, they are not worth
Owning, was she her mistress say you?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Her own mistress, her very mistress, sir, and all you saw
About, and in that house was hers.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: No plate, no jewels, nor no hangings?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Not a farthing, she is poor, sir, a poor shifting thing,

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: No money?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Abominable poor, as poor as we are,
Money as rare to her unless she steal it.
But for one civil gown her lady gave her,
She may go bare good gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I am mad now,
I think I am as poor as she, I am wide else,
One civil suit I have left too, and that's all,
And if she steal that she must flay me for it,
Where does she use?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: You may find truth as soon,
Alas a thousand concealed corners sir, she lurks in,
And here she gets a fleece, and there another,
And lives in mists and smokes where none can find her.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Is she a whore too?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Little better gentleman, I dare not say she is so sir, because
She is yours, sir, but these 5 years she has firked
A pretty living,
Until she came to serve; I fear he will knock my
Brains out for lying.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: She has served me faithfully,
A whore, and a thief, two excellent moral learning's
In one she saint, I hope to see her legend.
Have I been feared for my discoveries,
And courted by all women to conceal 'em,
Have I so long studied the art of this sex,
And read the warnings to young gentlemen:
Have I professed to tame the pride of ladies,
And make 'em bear all tests, and am I tricked now,
Caught in mine own noose, here's a royal left yet,
There's for your lodging and your meat for this week.
A silkworm lives at a more plentiful ordinary,
And sleeps in a sweeter box, farewell great grandmother,
If I do find you were an accessary,
'Tis but the cutting off too smoky minutes.
I'll hang ye presently.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: And I deserve it, I tell but truth.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Nor I, I am an ass mother. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the Duke, Medina, Juan de Castro, Alonzo, Sancho, Cacafogo, attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A goodly house.

sp.speaker: Juan,
sp.l: And richly furnished too sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Hung wantonly, I like that preparation,
It stirs the blood unto a hopeful banquet,
And intimates the mistress free and jovial,
I love a house where pleasure prepares welcome.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now Cacafogo, how like you this mansion,
'Twere a brave pawn.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I shall be master of it,
'Twas built for my bulk, the rooms are wide and spacious,
Airy, and full of ease, and that I love well,
I'll tell you when I taste the wine my lord,
And take the height of her table with my stomach,
how my affections stand to the young lady.

div.stage: Enter Margarita, Altea, ladies, and servants.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: All welcome to your grace, and to these soldiers,
You honour my poor house with your fair presence
Those few slight pleasures that inhabit here sir,
I do beseech your grace command, they are yours;
Your servant but preserves 'em to delight ye,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I thank ye lady, I am bold to visit ye.
Once more to bless mine eyes with your sweet beauty,
'Thas been a long night since you left the court,
For till I saw you now, no day broke to me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Bring in the Duke's meat.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: She is most excellent.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Most admirable fair as ere I looked on,
I had rather command her then my regiment.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I'll have a fling, 'tis but a thousand ducats,
Which I can cozen up again in ten days,
And some few jewels to justify my knavery,
Say i should marry her, she'll get more money
Than all my usury, put my knavery to it,
She appears the most unfallible way of purchase,
I could wish her a size or two stronger, for the encounter,
For I am like a lion where I lay hold,
But these lambs will endure a plaguy load,
And never bleat neither, that sir, time has taught us.
I am so virtuous now, I cannot speak to her,
The arrantest shame faced a●se, I broil away too.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why where's this dinner?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis not ready madam,
Nor shall not be until I know the guests too,
Nor are they fairly welcome till I bid 'em.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Is not this my Alferese he looks another thing, ●
Are miracles a foot again?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why sirrah, why sirrah you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I hear you saucy woman,
And as you are my wife command your absence,
And know your duty, 'tis the crown of modesty.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your wife?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes good my lord, I am her husband,
And pray take notice that I claim that honour,
And will maintain it.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: If thou beest her husband,
I am determined thou shall be my cuckold,
I'll be thy faithful friend.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Peace dirt and dunghill,
I will not lose my anger on a rascal,
Provoke me more, I'll beat thy blown body
Till thou rebound'st again like a tennis ball.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: This is miraculous.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Is this the fellow
That had the patience to become a fool,
A flirt fool, and on a sudden break,
As if he would show a wonder to the world
Both into bravery, and fortune too,
I much admire the man, i am astonished.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I'll be divorced immediately

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You shall not.
You shall not have so much will to be wicked.
I am more tender of your honour lady,
And of your age, you took me for a shadow.
You took me to gloss over your discredit,
To be your fool, you had thought you had found a coxcomb;
I am innocent of any foul dishonour I mean to ye,
Only I will be known to be your lord now,
And be a fair one too, or I will fall for't.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I do command ye from me thou poor fellow,
Thou cozened fool.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Thou cozened fool, 'tis not so,
I will not be commanded: I am above ye:
You may divorce me from your favour lady,
But from your state you never shall, I'll hold that,
And hold it to my use, the law allows it,
And then maintain your wantonness I'll wink at it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Am I braved thus in mine own house.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis mine madam,
you are deceived I am lord of it, I rule it and all that's in't,
You have nothing to do here madam,
But as a servant to sweep clean the lodgings,
And at my farther will to do me service,
And so I'll keep it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: As you love me give way.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It shall be better,
I will give none madam,
I stand upon the ground of mine own honour
And will maintain it, you shall know me now,
To be an understanding feeling man,
And sensible of what a woman aims at,
A young proud woman that has will to sail with,
An itching woman, that her blood provokes too,
I cast my cloud off and appear myself,
The master of this little piece of mischief,
And I will put a spell about your feet lady,
They shall not wander but where I give way now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is this the fellow that the people pointed at,
For the mere sign of man, the walking image,
He speaks wondrous highly.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: As a husband ought sir,
In his own house, and it becomes me well too,
I think your grace would grieve if you were put to it,
To have a wife or servant of your own,
For wives are reckoned in the rank of servants,
Under your own roof to command ye.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Brave, a strange conversion, thou shalt lead
In chief now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is there no difference betwixt her and you sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Not now lord, my fortune makes me even,
And as I am an honest man, I am nobler.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Get me my coach.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Let me see who dare get it
Till I command, I'll make him draw your coach too,
And eat your coach, (Which will be hard diet)
That executes your will; or take your coach lady,
I give you liberty, and take your people.
Which I turn off, and take your will abroad with ye,
Take all these freely, but take me no more,
And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Nay sir you shall not carry it
So bravely off, you shall not wrong a lady
In a high huffing strain, and think to bear it,
We stand not by as bawds to your brave fury,
To see a lady weep.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: They are tears of anger, I beseech ye note 'em not worth pity,
Wrung from her rage, because her will prevails not,
She would sound now if she could not cry,
Else they were excellent and I should grieve too,
But falling thus, they show nor sweet nor orient,
Put up my lord, this is oppression,
And calls the sword of justice to relieve me,
The law to lend her hand, the King to right me,
All which shall understand how you provoke me,
In mine own house to brave me, is this princely,
Then to my guard, and if I spare your grace,
And do not make this place your monument,
Too rich a tomb for such a rude behaviour,
I have a cause will kill a thousand of ye, mercy for me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Hold fair sir I beseech ye,
The gentleman but pleads his own right nobly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: He that dares strike against the husband's freedom,
The husband's curse stick to him, a tamed cuckold,
His wife be fair and young, but most dishonest,
Most impudent, and have no feeling of it,
No conscience to reclaim her from a monster,
Let her lie by him like a flattering ruin,
And at one instant kill both name and honour,
Let him be lost, no eye to weep his end,
Nor find no earth that's base enough to bury him,
Now sir fall on, I am ready to oppose ye.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I have better thought, I pray sir use your wife well.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Mine own humanity will teach me that sir,
And now you are all welcome, all, and we'll to dinner,
This is my wedding day.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I'll cross your joy yet.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I have seen a miracle, hold thine own soldier,
Sure they dare fight in fire that conquer women.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Has beaten all my loose thoughts out of me,
As if he had threshed 'em out o'th husk.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Save ye, which is the lady of the house.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That's she sir, that pretty lady,
If you would speak with her.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Don Michael Leon, another darer come?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray do not know me, I am full of business,
When I have more time I'll be merry with ye,
It is the woman, good madam tell me truly,
Had you a maid called Estifania?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Yes truly had I.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Was she a maid do you think?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I dare not swear for her,
For she had but a scant fame.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Was she your kinswoman?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Not that I ever knew, now I look better
I think you married her, give you much joy sir,
You may reclaim her 'twas a wild young girl.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Give me a halter, is not this house mine madam▪
Was not she owner of it, pray speak truly.

sp.speaker: Marg
sp.l: No, certainly, I am sure my money paid for it,
And I ne'er remember yet I gave it you sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The hangings and the plate too?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: All are mine sir,
And every thing you see about the building,
She only kept my house when I was absent,
And so ill kept it, I was weary of her.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: What a devil ails he?

sp.speaker: Juan
sp.l: Is possessed I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Where is your maid?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Do not you know that have her?
She is yours now, why should I look after her,
Since that first hour I came I never saw her.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I saw her later would the devil had had her,
it is all true I find, a wildfire take her●▪

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Is thy wife with child don Michael? thy excellent wife.
Art thou a man yet.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: When shall we come and visit thee?

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: And eat some rare fruit, thou hast admirable orchards,
You are so jealous now, pox a your jealousy,
How scurvily you look.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pre thee leave fooling,
I am in no humour now to fool and prattle,
Did she ne'er play the wag with you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Yes many times, so often that I was ashamed to keep her,
But I forgave her sir, in hope she would mend still,
And had not you o'th instant married her,
I had put her off.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I thank ye I am blessed still,
Which way soe'er I turn I am a made man,
Miserably gulled beyond recovery.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You'll stay and dine.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Certain I cannot captain,
Hark in thine ear, I am the arrant'st puppy,
The miserablest ass, but I must leave ye,
I am in haste, in haste, bless ye good madam,
And you prove as good as my wife. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Will you come near sir, will your grace but honour me,
And taste our dinner, you are nobly welcome,
All anger's passed I hope, and I shall serve ye.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Thou art the stock of men, and I admire thee. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus 4. Scaena 1.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'll go to a conjurer but I'll find this polecat,
This pilfering whore, a plague of veils I cry,
And covers for the impudence of women,
Their sanctity in show will deceive devils,
It is my evil angel let me bless me.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: 'Tis he, I am caught, I must stand to it stoutly,
And show no shake of fear, I see he is angry,
Vexed at the uttermost.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My worthy wife,
I have been looking of your modesty,
All the town over.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: My most noble husband,
I am glad I have found ye, for in truth I am weary,
Weary and lame with looking out your lordship.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I have been in bawdy houses.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I believe ye, and very lately too.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray ye pardon me,
To seek your ladyship, I have been in cellars,
In private cellars, where the thirsty bawds
Hear your confessions; I have been at plays,
To look you out amongst the youthful actors,
At puppet shows, you are mistress of the motions;
At gosshippings I hearkened after ye,
But amongst those confusions of lewd tongues
There's no distinguishing beyond a Babel.
I was amongst the nuns because you sing well,
But they say yours are bawdy songs, they mourn for ye,
And last I went to church to seek you out,
'Tis so long since you were there, they have forgotten ye.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You have had a pretty progress, I'll tell mine now
To look you out, I went to twenty taverns.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And are you sober?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Yes, I reel not yet sir,
Where I saw twenty drunk most of 'em soldiers,
There I had great hope to find you disguised too.
From hence to'th dicing house, there I found
Quarrels needless, and senseless, swords, and pots, and candlesticks,
Tables, and stools, and all in one confusion,
And no man knew his friend, I left this chaos,
And to the chirurgeons went, he willed me stay,
For says he learnedly, if he be tippled,
Twenty to one he whores, and then I bear of him.
If he be mad, he quarrels, then he comes ●oo,
I sought ye where no safe thing would have ventured
Amongst diseases, base, and vild, vild women,
For I remembered your old Roman axiom,
The more the danger, still the more the honour.
Last to your confessor I came, who told me
You were too proud to pray, and here I have found ye.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: She bears up bravely and the rogue is witty,
But I shall dash it instantly to nothing,
Here leave we off our wanton languages,
And now conclude we in a sharper tongue.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Why am I cozened,
Why am I abused.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Thou most vild, base, abominable.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Thou stinking overstewd, poor, pocky

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Do you echo me?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Yes sir, and go before ye,
And round about ye, why do you rail at me
For that, that was your own sin, your own knavery.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: And brave me too.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You had best now draw your sword captain,
Draw it upon a woman, do brave captain,
Upon your wife, o most renowned captain.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: A plague upon thee, answer me directly,
Why didst thou marry me?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: To be my husband;
I had thought you had had infinite, but I'm cozened.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Why didst thou flatter me, and show me wonders,
A house, and riches, when they are but shadows,
Shadows to me.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Why did you work on me,
It was but my part to requite you sir,
With your strong soldier's wit, and swore you would bring me
So much in chains, so much in jewels husband,
So much in right rich clothes.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Thou hast 'em rascal
I gave 'em to thy hands, my trunks and all;
And thou hast opened 'em, and sold my treasure.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Sir, there's your treasure, sell it to a tinker
To mend old kettles, is this noble usage,
Let all the world view here the captain's treasure,
A man would think now these were worthy matters:
Here's a shooing-horn chain, gilt over, how it scenteth
Worse than the mouldy dirty heel it served for,
And here's another of a lesser value,
So little, I would shame to tie my dog in't,
These are my jointure, blush and save a labour,
Or these else will blush for ye.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: A fire subtle ye, are ye so crafty.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Here's a goodly jewel,
Did not you win this at Goletta captain,
Or took it in the field from some brave bashaw,
How it sparkles like an old lady's eyes,
And fills each room with light like a close lantern,
This would do rarely in an abbey window,
To cousin pilgrims.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Prithee leave prating.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: And here's a chain of whitings eyes for pearls,
A mussel-monger would have made a better.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Nay, prithee wife, my clothes, my clothes.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I'll tell ye,
Your clothes are parallels to these, all counterfeit.
Put these and them on, you are a man of copper,
A kind of candlestick, these you thought my husband,
To have cozened me withal, but I am quit with you.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Is there no house then, nor no grounds about it?
No plate nor hangings?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: There are none sweet husband,
Shadow for shadow is an equal justice,
Can you rail now, pray put your fury up sir,
And speak great words, you are a soldier, thunder.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I will speak little, I have played the fool,
And so I am rewarded.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You have spoke well sir,
and now I see you are so conformable,
I'll heighten you again, go to your house,
They are packing to be gone, you must sup there,
I'll meet ye, and bring clothes, and clean shirts after,
And all things shall be well; I'll colt ye once more,
And teach ye to bring copper.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Tell me one thing,
I do beseech thee tell me, tell me truth wife,
However I forgive thee, art thou honest,
The beldame swore.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I bid her tell you so sir,
It was my plot, alas my credulous husband,
The lady told you too.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Most strange things of thee.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Still 'twas my way, and all to try your sufferance,
And she denied the house.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: She knew me not;
No, nor no title that I had.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: 'Twas well carried;
No more, I am right and straight.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I would believe thee,
But heaven knows how my heart is, will ye follow me.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I'll be there straight.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am fooled, yet dare not find it. Exit Perez.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Go silly fool, thou mayst be a good soldier
In open field, but for our private service
Thou art an ass, I'll make thee so or miss else. Ent. Cac.
Here comes another trout that I must tickle,
And tickle daintily, I have lost my end else.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: May I crave your leave sir?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Prithee be answered, thou shalt crave no leave,
I am in my meditations, do not vex me,
A beaten thing, but this hour a most bruised thing,
That people had compassion on, it looked so.
The next sir Palmerin, here's fine proportion,
An ass, and then an elephant, sweet justice,
There's no way left to come at her now, no craving,
If money could come near, yet I would pay him;
I have a mind to make him a huge cuckold,
And money may do much, a thousand ducats,
'Tis but the letting blood of a rank heir.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Pray ye hear me.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I know thou hast some wedding ring to pawn now.
Of silver and guilt with a blind posy in't,
Love and a mill-horse should go round together,
Or thy child's whistle, or thy squirrels chain,
I'll none of 'em, I would she did but know me,
Or would this fellow had but use of money,
That I might come in any way.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: I am gone sir,
And I shall tell the beauty sent me to ye,
The lady Margarita.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Stay I prithee,
What is thy will, I turn me wholly to ye,
And talk now till thy tongue ache, I will hear ye.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: She would entreat ye sir.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: She shall command sir,
Let it be so I beseech thee my sweet gentlewoman,
Do not forget thyself.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: She does command then,
This courtesy, because she knows you are noble.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Your mistress by the way.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: My natural mistress,
Upon these jewels sir, they are fair and rich●
And view 'em right.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: To doubt 'em is an heresy.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: A thousand ducats, 'tis upon necessity
Of present use, her husband sir is stubborn.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Long may he be so.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: She desires withal, a better knowledge of your parts and person,
And when you please to do her so much honour.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Comelet's dispatch.

sp.speaker: Estif.
